content.description: This line follows the right rising crack above the smaller boulders. Not a great quality problem overall. If you want to do a V0, do Rooster's Holiday or Popsicle.
content.protection: Pretty bad landing. Definitely use a couple pads if you really want to try this one
content.location: the climb is above the mess of small boulders

content.description: This problem truly has it all. Start matched on a chest height jug at the right end of the overhung face. Move left and then up into a body tension crimpy crux sequence. Go up over the lip of the overhang into slopey territory. Finish off with a (safer than it feels) heady topout.
content.protection: I usually try this one with three pads. One on the ground, one leaning against the smaller boulder, and one on top of the smaller boulder, with a spotter on top. It is a hassle to set up and protect, but this climb is awesome.

content.description: Sit start in the semi cave that the two big boulders make. Go right and up starting at the chest height edge.
content.protection: one or two pads to make the sit start comfortable in the cave

content.description: The face climb to the left of Slabadon, which is the arete climb on this tall and somewhat dirty part of the massive second set boulder. Start on chest height crimps, go up and left and eventually top out very high on easier terrain.
content.protection: One or two pads with a spotter.
content.location: The tall face climb on the lichen covered boulder. The start of the climb faces a tree about 5 feet away.

content.description: Not to be confused with the classic SlObadon on the First Set. However, this climb is still pretty good. Stand start at the vertical seam at 6 feet. Climb up the arete and top out high on sometimes dirty holds
Stand stat on the arete. Go right to the lip. The block is off.
Start down low right along the left rising lip. Pumpy but easy traverse to a top out on the big triangular horn.
The best V0 at Makenzie. Stand start at the big vertical crack. Climb up using the crack and a couple horizontal holds to the right. Top out pretty high.
content.protection: One or two pads due to the height.
content.location: The tall vertical crack on the right side of the slabby face.

content.description: Make the start as for the greatroof then head up to the over hang once out on the lip make start to make the traverse across. about half way across there is a scrubbed patch of moss on the hump right above where your head should be. head up the hump on tiny little crimps. this is a fun variation to great wall that gives you some where to end up.
content.protection: a pad or two and a good spotter

content.description: Stand start at the right end of the head height horizontal crack. Traverse left to the start of the Great Roof of China. There are a few variations of this route. You can traverse into the Little Roof of Taiwan, skipping the sit start, or you can go for a long climb and finish the Great Roof of China once you get to the start.
content.protection: one or two or three or four pads depending on what length of traverse your'e doing or what variation you're doing

content.description: Start standing on the blunt arete or the far left side of the face. Climb up on crimps to the right rising crack. Follow the crack to the top.
content.protection: One or two pads depending on how you prefer to start it.
content.location: This will be the first route you see when approaching the second set.

content.description: Sit start under the low overhang, which is under a little roof at about 8 feet. Shoot up to the head height horn, climb around the overhang, and top out
Same start as for Little Roof. Get a high right foot and power up off it to the big block jug up and right.

One of the most unique boulder problems I've ever seen. It starts at the head height horizontal hand crack below the great big roof, moves up and left to the top of the right facing corner where it meets the ceiling. Slap out for the lip of the roof, traverse right to the big horn, and top out on the blunt right facing, left rising corner.
content.protection: Probable three pads for this one due to the wandering nature of the climbing and the height of the top out. If you cant stick the lip of the roof, you may swing back and into a tree. Always good to have a spotter positioned there. The landing on this has been improved over time by removing pesky rocks and stumps.

content.description: Start with your hands in the slot for the Great roof start and dyno directly up to the arete of the roof. Totally awesome.
content.protection: lots of pads and a spotter

content.description: Stand start at the slab. Go up the slab and over the bulge to the left. Top out high using the right rising seam. Generally agreed to be harder than V2, even though it is documented as such.
content.protection: Definitely two pads for this one. It's tall and committing
content.location: This is one of the first real noticeable climbs on the Second Set Boulder when you first get there from the First Set. It is the big slab just to the right of where the trail puts out.

content.description: Climb the thin holds beneath the big horn at 10 feet.

This is the first boulder of the second set that you see first when you approach from the first set. It has 20 problems on it and is really more of a tight cluster of rocks than one individual boulder.
